Award.AwardTitle: Ultraslow crustal accretion at the Mid-Cayman Spreading Center: Mantle exhumation or magmatism?
Award.AbstractNarration:
The seismic structure of the Mid-Cayman Spreading Center (MCSC) will be investigated to determine the extent to which magmatism contributes to crustal structure of an ultra-slow oceanic rift segment. As part of a larger international project, seismic data will be acquired along five profiles, from the ridge axis to ~10 Myr old flank, and from the spreading segment center to the transform walls. Two main ideas will be addressed: (1) Whether the MCSC hosts oceanic core complexes of exhumed crustal or mantle materials; (2) Whether crustal thickness variations in the MCSC reflect inhibition of magmatism as the spreading-segment ends are approached. Ocean bottom seismograph data will constrain tomographic models of velocity structure, from which crustal thickness, its variability, and/or mantle properties can be inferred. Recently acquired bathymetry and gravity data will be combined with prior trackline data and used as the basis for integrated seismic, gravity, and morphologic interpretation.

Up to 20-30% of the world's oceanic spreading centers rift at ultraslow rates of less than 20 mm/yr, and expose a range of lower-crustal and upper mantle rock. These ultraslow systems host hydrothermal fields with chemical and biological activity that are distinct from faster spreading chemosynthetic systems, and have relevance for understanding the development of early life on Earth. This joint US-German-UK project strengthens international collaboration on studies of seafloor spreading. A graduate student will participate in all phases of the US portion of the study, receiving training in a range of marine geophysical techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Up to 20-30% of the world's oceanic spreading centers rift at ultraslow rates of less than 20 mm/yr, and expose a range of lower-crustal and upper mantle rock. These ultraslow rifts host hydrothermal fields with chemical and biological activity that are distinct from faster spreading chemosynthetic systems. To better understand the links between deep crustal and surface processes at ultraslow spreading centers, a joint US-German-UK team has collaborated on a seismic refraction imaging study of the Mid-Cayman Spreading Center (MCSC), where the North American and Caribbean plates separate at a speed of 15 mm/yr. The MCSC is known to have two hydrothermal vents. The Beebe vent is a black smoker vent in a deep-lying lava field in the northern half of the spreading center, and the Von Damm vent field is situated on the crest of Mount Dent, an oceanic core complex in the middle of the MCSC. Understanding the heat source that drives venting, and the degree to which tectonic faults on the core complex interact with seawater and mantle melts, were two main goals of this study.

In April 2015 we gathered six ocean-bottom seismic refraction lines parallel to and across the MCSC. The instruments were contributed by the University of Texas at Austin, GEOMAR, and Durham University. With the air-gun array of the German vessel R/V Meteor we shot seismic refraction data along each line, which were recorded by seismometers with an average spacing of 4.5 km. An additional 15 GEOMAR ocean-bottom seismometers were deployed in the area for three weeks to record local earthquakes. With the wide-angle seismic data we carried out tomographic inversions, which produced compressional and shear-wave seismic velocity images of the crust and uppermost mantle along the seismic lines.

The seismic velocity image for seismic line P01 along the axial valley shows how extension and magmatism along the plate boundary are organized in two spreading segments, separated by the Mount Dent core complex. Lava fields north and south of mount dent appear to be fed by shallow volcanic centers, which we image as low seismic velocity zones. The upper crust is as thick as 1.5-2.0 km beneath these basaltic areas, whereas mantle rock is exhumed by a detachment fault on the flank of Mount Dent. The Beebe vent field, which lies in the northern spreading segment, is characterized by low upper crustal seismic velocities (3 km/s) which we attribute to fracturing of the basaltic rocks at this hydrothermal system.

The seismic velocity image for seismic Line P02, across Mount Dent and the MCSC axial valley, shows a sub-surface dipping anomaly in the core complex that we interpret as a gabbroic body. This intrusion may have formed as a flat-lying, large sill on-axis, and rotated into its current position after 2 million years of exhumation along the detachment fault. Deep in the core complex we imaged lower seismic velocities, which may be evidence for either ongoing deep hydrothermal fluid circulation or intrusive magmatic sills, both of which could drive the Von Damm vent field. We conclude that the transient magmatism and variable crustal thickness at ultraslow-spreading centers create conditions for long-lived hydrothermal venting that may be widespread.

Other seismic refraction lines on the older flanks of the MCSC show compressional seismic velocities between 4.0 km/s and 7.4 km/s that could represent either serpentinized mantle rock, or igneous rock produced by magmatism on the MCSC. However, the ratio of compressional seismic velocity and shear-wave velocity Vp/Vs is often greater than 1.9 at the seafloor, while uplifted older oceanic core complexes may contain more igneous crust. The Cayman Trough therefore provides a window into mid-ocean ridge dynamics that switch between magma-rich and magma-poor oceanic crustal accretion, including exhumation of serpentinized mantle covering about 25% of the seafloor in this region.
